 Introduction
Theoretical Mechanisms
Evidence from US Multinational Activity Abroad

Motivation and Introduction

(cid:73) Multinationals (MNCs) today manage complex global operations that

serve multiple markets:

On average, US aﬃliates abroad sell 75% of their output in the host
country, ship 7% back to the US, and 18% to other countries.

(cid:73) This blends features of three FDI motives that the literature has

traditionally treated in isolation:

(cid:73) Horizontal: local sales to the host-country market

(cid:73) Vertical: aﬃliate exports of intermediate inputs

(cid:73) Export-platform: aﬃliate exports of ﬁnal goods to third-country markets

(cid:73) Above stylized fact suggests that reality is much more complex.

Overview: Findings

We use the comprehensive and conﬁdential BEA data on the operations of US
multinationals abroad, 1989-2009.

Better ﬁnancial development in the FDI host country associated with:

1. A larger number of aﬃliates.

2. Higher levels of aggregate aﬃliate sales to the local, US and third-country

markets.

 Introduction
Theoretical Mechanisms
Evidence from US Multinational Activity Abroad

Overview: Findings (cont.)

Rationalize these patterns through a combination of two forces:

(i) Competition eﬀect:

Financial development in the host country promotes entry of domestic ﬁrms

⇒ Local market becomes more competitive

⇒ MNC aﬃliates orient their sales away from serving the local market, towards

other markets instead. (Matching facts 3 and 4.)

(ii) Financing eﬀect:

If MNCs rely on host-country ﬁnancing . . .

⇒ Financial development in the host country facilitates entry of more MNC

aﬃliates (extensive margin)

⇒ In the aggregate, sales levels to all three markets increase. (Matching facts

1 and 2.)

Setting

Consider a FDI host economy where:

(cid:73) There are two types of production entities: (i) domestic ﬁrms; and (ii)

MNC aﬃliates

(cid:73) Each ﬁrm/aﬃliate produces a distinct diﬀerentiated variety

Think: Firm heterogeneity a la Melitz (2003), HMY (2004)

(cid:73) Varieties are substitutes in consumption

(cid:73) A separate entry margin for both domestic ﬁrms and MNC aﬃliates

(cid:73) MNC aﬃliates in particular face a decision over how much to sell in the
host (HOR(a)), home (RET (a)), and third-country markets (PLA(a)).

(Note: See the paper for a formalization in a stylized three-country setting.)

Credit constraints in the host country

(cid:73) Assume domestic ﬁrms need external ﬁnance for the ﬁxed cost of

operations in each period.

(cid:73) In the presence of ﬁnancing frictions: A margin of ﬁrms denied access to

credit, e.g., due to an inability to credibly commit to repayment.

(cid:73) Improvements in host-country ﬁnancial development therefore facilitate

entry by these domestic ﬁrms.

Empirical Hypotheses

Competition Eﬀect: Improved ﬁnancial development in the host country
induces entry of domestic ﬁrms

⇒ Increased competition in the host market

⇒ MNCs re-orient sales away from the local market towards other markets.

⇒ A decrease in each individual aﬃliate’s horizontal sales, both in levels and

in shares; converse response for return and platform sales.

Introducing the ﬁnancing eﬀect

Well-documented that MNCs seek host-country ﬁnancing:

(cid:73) Feinberg and Phillips (2004): About two-thirds of US MNC aﬃliate debt

comes from local borrowing

(cid:73) Independently veriﬁed this in the 1999 and 2004 benchmark BEA surveys.

(cid:73) Moreover: Desai et al. (2004) and Antr`as et al. (2009) show that the
share of local vs parent ﬁnancing obtained by aﬃliates responds to
host-country ﬁnancial development.

(cid:73) While parent ﬁrms clearly also raise ﬁnance in the home country. . .

. . . Host-country ﬁnancing is still necessary, e.g., if there are transactions
costs associated with moving funds across borders, or if home-country
creditors cannot eﬀectively monitor aﬃliate activity abroad.

Hypothesis
When both the competition and ﬁnancing eﬀects are present, the responses to
improved host-country ﬁnancial development at the individual aﬃliate level are
similar. Moreover, aggregating across aﬃliates in the host country, if the
ﬁnancing eﬀect is suﬃciently strong, one observes:

(i) an increase in the number of aﬃliates;

(ii) an increase in HOR, PLA, RET , and TOT ; as well as
TOT , an increase in PLA

and host ﬁrms in local ﬁnancial markets. To better understand how local

Motivation and Introduction
(cid:73) Multinationals (MNCs) today manage complex global operations that
serve multiple markets:
On average, US aﬃliates abroad sell 75% of their output in the host
country, ship 7% back to the US, and 18% to other countries.
(cid:73) This blends features of three FDI motives that the literature has
traditionally treated in isolation:
(cid:73) Horizontal: local sales to the host-country market
(cid:73) Vertical: aﬃliate exports of intermediate inputs
(cid:73) Export-platform: aﬃliate exports of ﬁnal goods to third-country markets
(cid:73) Above stylized fact suggests that reality is much more complex.
